results.title: Amazing H2o
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Episode 2: amazing H2O’ starts with the story of Henry Cavendish (Mark Allen), a rich scientist in the 17th century who made it his mission in life to discover the properties of water. His persistence gave us the H2O chemical name. With 70% of the earth covered in water, it is surprising to learn that scientists know more about the qualities of ice than water itself. Exploring both the realm of the known and unknown, this episode covers the following topics; surface tension, anti-gravitational behaviour, solutions, emulsions, ice, gas, evaporation, crystals. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: The Water planet
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Waterworks’ is an in depth series produced by the ABC on water and covers areas such as; human usage, molecular properties and the role of water in the ecology. ‘The Water planet’, first in the series, details broadly the concepts that govern the function of water and investigates the presence of water on earth and in space. The film starts with the premise that all life on earth is based on water and digresses to detail this relationship. The following subjects are covered from the presence of water in space, water cycles, water ecology, function of chemical parts in water, weather patterns and its relationship to water, water and plantlife, the oceans. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: Language at twelve (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
Intended primarily to emphasise the diversity and complexity of language in the life of a 12-year-old. This film focuses on two 12-year-olds who are involved in a school language project. Shows their interaction with a sufficient number of significant people in their lives for us to gain an impression of how the demands upon their speech shift. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Reading for meaning: the Goodman Model (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch your language”
Understanding the reading process. Professors Ken and Yetta Goodman discuss the problems of the teaching of reading with a class of teachers in Australia. Docments some of their main propositions relating to language in use, miscue analysis and reading. Stresses the need to focus on the strengths of children and not simply the weaknesses.
Suitable for teacher level.

results.title: Talking shop: demands on language
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield, Australia. Dept. of Education and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Watch Your Language”.
A teenage boy and girl, when interviewed for vacation jobs in a store, reveal a limited capacity to express themselves. Describes their feelings about their jobs, their fellow workers and shows how they adapted to the situation. Useful for linguistics studies and career advisers. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels and tertiary teacher education.

results.title: Independent company
results.creator_credit: John Tatoulis, Colin South and Media World
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Warriors”.
The story of Sparrow Force, the Australian 2/2 Independent Company, a specially trained troop of Australian soldiers sent to join Dutch forces in Timor in 1941, to defend Northern Australia against the Japanese advance. The program uses interviews with surviving Company members, as well as their Japanese opponents, mixed with re-enactments of their experiences. The interviews reveal that without the selfless assistance of the Timorese, the Australian troops would not have survived. The program also features footage shot by Academy Award winning Australian news cameraman, Damien Parer, who was killed in action in New Guinea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Tatoulis, Colin South and Media World

results.title: I Hope the war will be over soon
results.creator_credit: John Ruane, I. James Wilson, John Tristram and Juniper Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Warriors”.
This program examines the impact of the Vietnam War on three Australian ex-servicemen, a Vietnamese student and a Cambodian refugee. Brian Day, a member of the Australian Regular Army for 21 years, believed the Army was an honourable profession, but his experiences in Vietnam and afterwards in Australia, have disillusioned him. He now works for the Australia-Vietnam Society and is suffering from the effects of chemical defoliants. Greg Lockhart served in the Australian Embassy in Saigon and has since devoted himself to Vietnamese history. He is married to Monique Hoa Phan, a Vietnamese student stranded in Australia after the fall of Saigon. The program also includes extensive interviews with an Aboriginal serviceman now working for the rights of his own people in Alice Springs and Cambodian, An Veng, who now lives in Australia but who served as driver and sound recordist for Australian war journalist, Neil Davis, during the Vietnam War.
results.title_for_label: I Hope the war will be over soon
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Ruane, I. James Wilson, John Tristram and Juniper Films
